instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.VCC_MAIN: What is VCC_MAIN? VCC_MAIN is the main power rail in an iPhone that comes from the battery, similar to PPBUS_G3H in a macbook..

threads.title: iPhone 6S - No Backlight (<SIGNAL>VCC_MAIN</SIGNAL>  == <SIGNAL>PP_LCM_BL_ANODE</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Hi, First time repairing an iPhone 6(s) here.

I bought a iPhone 6s from a seller with what was told a broken screen, so I assumed it was just a screen replacement job or at worst replacing the backlight filter or whatever they managed to break.
However from what it looks like the phone has been worked on before (some parts are pretty ugly soldered, but working though) however I think, I [B]hope[/B] they gave up once they had to remove the shields. I can't compare it with an actually untouched 6(s) since I've never seen one with my own eyes.

The issue is that the backlight (I think) is not being boosted, <SIGNAL>PP_LCM_BL_ANODE</SIGNAL> (which should be 35V following the schematic) is exactly the same as <SIGNAL>VCC_MAIN</SIGNAL> (which was about ~3.33V, IIRC).

Is it possible one of the coils decided to stop boosting and just straight on pass <SIGNAL>VCC_MAIN</SIGNAL>? Might the <CHIP>U4020</CHIP> chip be the issue of it all? I have no idea where to look, anyone any ideas/tips?

This is how the area looks: [URL]https://i.imgur.com/l5qZZvJ.jpg[/URL]

Thanks in advance!

threads.title: iPhone 6S - No Backlight (<SIGNAL>VCC_MAIN</SIGNAL>  == <SIGNAL>PP_LCM_BL_ANODE</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
Check FL4211, I usually just put a wire instead if no good. That's what it usually is for me. Tip: use hot air at 200 degrees to get rid of black goop and an exacto blade.

(Yay! This is fucking amazing!  I used to be the one asking all the questions - Now I can help out if I can. Gimme a cookie and a brownie point !)

threads.title: iPhone 6S - No Backlight (<SIGNAL>VCC_MAIN</SIGNAL>  == <SIGNAL>PP_LCM_BL_ANODE</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
FL4211 won't be the issue as the voltage is already equal to <SIGNAL>VCC_MAIN</SIGNAL> at the start of the powerline.

Thanks for the tip about getting rid of the black goop stuff thoguh, helps a lot! I just kinda poked it away at first haha.

threads.title: iPhone 6S - No Backlight (<SIGNAL>VCC_MAIN</SIGNAL>  == <SIGNAL>PP_LCM_BL_ANODE</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
After inspecting the area for a second time I noticed <DIODE>D4021</DIODE> looked kinda shaky. I just gave it a very small touch with my tweezers and it fell right off.

There was definitely someone here before because the pads and their solder looked like crap, they were almost ripped off / destroyed. I removed the old solder and tried to move the pads back with success.

Then I soldered <DIODE>D4021</DIODE> back on and, done! The backlight is properly functioning again

I'm unsure if <DIODE>D4021</DIODE> would've been the actual issue though, its an important part, but would it cause the backlight not to boost? I want to make sure I actually fixed the issue not just because I applied heat in that area

threads.title: iPhone 6S - No Backlight (<SIGNAL>VCC_MAIN</SIGNAL>  == <SIGNAL>PP_LCM_BL_ANODE</SIGNAL>)
threads.message:
You mean <DIODE>D1501</DIODE>? Right?

Edit: Sorry.  iPhone 6S not 6 -LOL.
I've never had one go down there yet.  But cool.  You showed me something : )
